text: Infection with Theileria annulata induces expression of <extra_id_0> matrix metalloproteinase 9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and transcription factor AP-1 in bovine leucocytes .
Theileria annulata infects bovine leucocytes and results in their reversible transformation such that they become immortalised and metastatic .
The present study describes parasite - induced changes in host cell gene expression which have a direct bearing on this transformation process .
T . annulata-infected leucocytes produce a number of novel metalloproteinase activities .
One of these , previously called B1 , is a 97-kDa protein which is secreted in large amounts and has been purified from protein - free , conditioned medium .
An antiserum to this enzyme was used to isolate a cDNA clone .

The predicted protein sequence of B1 is 81 % identical to human <extra_id_0> matrix metalloproteinase 9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> MMP9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , demonstrating that it is the bovine homologue of this enzyme .

RNAase protection assays demonstrated that the <extra_id_0> MMP9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity , unique to infected cells , is due to increased <extra_id_0> MMP9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA levels .
We also assayed the levels of transcription factor AP-1 and demonstrated that it was constitutively present in increased amounts in Theileria-infected cells .
In addition we assayed the level of mRNA encoding <extra_id_0> c-Fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a common component of AP-1 and observed that it was indeed up-regulated in infected cells .

Since AP-1 is implicated in the control of the cell cycle , and <extra_id_0> MMP9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> can confer metastatic properties , these results are of considerable significance with respect to the transformed phenotype induced by Theileria infection .
